New Records: Freddie Freeman tied a World Series record with 12 RBIs.
Shohei Ohtani authored the first 50-home run, 50-steal season in MLB history.
Key Match Events: The Dodgers mounted a title-winning comeback after falling behind by five runs in the first three innings.
Freddie Freeman and Teoscar Hernández delivered clutch hits in the fifth inning.
The Dodgers scored two eighth-inning runs off of two sacrifice flies to take the lead.
Walker Buehler emerged for the save in the ninth inning.
Freddie Freeman hit a two-run single in the fifth inning.
Teoscar Hernández blasted a two-run double in the fifth inning.
Mookie Betts drove in the go-ahead run with a sacrifice fly in the eighth inning.
Blake Treinen and Walker Buehler combined to secure the final six outs.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers' ownership group emphasized the importance of winning to Shohei Ohtani during his recruitment.
Post-Match Reflections: Walker Buehler expressed pride in being part of the Dodgers organization.
Manager Dave Roberts highlighted the resilience and fight of the team.
Freddie Freeman reflected on the special nature of the team.
Mookie Betts expressed his love for his teammates.
Shohei Ohtani felt honored to be part of the team and win a World Series.
Blake Treinen appreciated the trust placed in him by the manager.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers won the World Series with a 7-6 victory over the Yankees, securing a four-games-to-one series win.
Freddie Freeman was named World Series MVP.
The Dodgers led the majors with 98 wins in the regular season.
The Dodgers faced numerous challenges throughout the season, including injuries and scandals.
The Dodgers' comeback in Game 5 was the biggest come-from-behind win ever mounted by a club trying to close out a World Series.
